Clojure - Thriving in the dynamically type-checked hell scape of Clojure

2023/07/24
This article was written by an AI ðŸ¤–. The original article can be found here.

The article highlights the author's experience with Clojure, a dynamically type-checked programming language, and addresses common concerns about writing code without types. The author acknowledges that the nuances of strong and weak typing, as well as static vs dynamic type checking, can be lost on people. They attribute their cognitive model of writing code to their early experiences with programming in C and using tools like GEdit and the command line.

The author emphasizes the importance of reading code and building muscle memory to navigate through codebases, as documentation can often be outdated. They argue that having less code in the developer's head leads to better software development, and that dynamic type checking in Clojure can be addressed through the use of docstrings and idioms, which are more descriptive than type declarations on function arguments.

For developers interested in Clojure, the article provides insights into the mindset required to thrive in a dynamically type-checked language and offers alternative approaches to understanding and writing code.
